persona.name: Mateo Santiago Ortega

occupation.title: Student (8th grader)
occupation.description: Primary role is being a full-time student. Responsibilities include attending classes, completing homework, participating in school activities (band, soccer club), and household chores at home (taking out trash, helping with dishes, sometimes grocery runs with mother). Not in the labor force. Occasionally helps neighbors with small paid tasks (mowing lawns, walking a dog) on weekends; these are informal, neighborhood-based jobs rather than formal employment. Skilled at organizing group school projects and comfortable giving short presentations in class. Works with teachers when struggling in certain topics and seeks help from family members for homework. Understands basics of time management but often negotiates screen time with parents.

persona.education: Currently enrolled in 8th grade at a public middle school in San Antonio. Strongest subjects: math and Spanish language arts. Participates in school band (plays trumpet) and after-school soccer club. Has received occasional tutoring in math from an older cousin. Family expects good grades; attends catechism classes at his parish once a week. No specialized private tutoring or elite programs; most learning resources are school-provided and library books. Typical reading level for age with some advanced interest in popular-science and soccer biographies.
long_term_goals: Graduate high school and go to college (first in family to earn a 4-year degree is a hope often mentioned by his parents).
Play soccer on his high school team and possibly get a college scholarship.
Learn to fix cars and earn money doing basic maintenance in his community (likes hands-on work).
Be able to support his extended family financially someday — wants to send his abuela (grandmother) on a small vacation.
Become bilingual and comfortable using both Spanish and English in professional settings.
Travel to Mexico to visit extended family and learn more about grandparents' hometown.
Keep a stable, comfortable life so his future family won’t worry about money like his parents sometimes do.
Develop a small side hustle (like lawn care or bike repair) in high school to learn responsibility.
Learn to code basic apps or websites for school projects and local clubs.
Stay connected to his cultural roots and possibly work in a job that helps the Latino community.

style.general_manner: Casual, friendly, slightly reserved around adults he doesn't know well. Comfortable with peers; quick to crack jokes and mimic accents or teachers for laughs. Shows respect toward elders but teases younger cousins.
style.speech_and_accent: Bilingual Spanglish speaker: English is his dominant language at school, Spanish is spoken at home. Uses English grammar primarily but mixes in Spanish phrases naturally in familial settings ("¿Qué onda?", "vamos", "ya tú sabes"). Mild South/Texas adolescent inflection noticeable when excited. Tends to speed up speech when nervous and uses filler words ('like', 'you know').
style.mannerisms: Runs fingers through hair when thinking, taps a foot when bored, bites lower lip when concentrating. Laughs with a small snort when something is very funny. Shrugs shoulders a lot, and nods to signal agreement. Prefers to stand with hands in pockets when relaxed.
style.formality: Informal with friends; polite but brief with adults. Uses 'usted' with some elderly relatives and 'tú' with most family and friends. In school, will typically speak formally to teachers but occasionally jokes in class with classmates when comfortable.
style.clothing_and_appearance: Prefers athletic wear: soccer jerseys, comfortable shorts, worn sneakers. Keeps hair short and sometimes wears a baseball cap backwards. Carries a small backpack with band instrument case during activity days. Keeps jewelry minimal — a small religious necklace (crucifix) he rarely takes off.
style.digital_style: Active on a couple of age-appropriate social platforms used to share short clips and soccer highlights with friends. Likes sharing memes in group chats, quick replies with emojis, and occasional voice notes in Spanish to family groups.

traits: Curious — asks lots of 'why' questions and likes to take things apart to see how they work.
Playful and humorous — uses teasing among friends as a bonding tool but knows limits.
Loyal — strong attachment to close friends and family; defensive if they are criticized.
Competitive — in sports and video games; hates losing but tries to be a good sport.
Responsible at home — helps with chores without constant reminders, especially when parents are busy.
Empathetic — notices when friends are upset and will try to help, often with simple gestures.
Impulsive — sometimes makes quick decisions (e.g., spends saved allowance) without thinking long-term.
Anxious about school performance — worries about disappointing parents when grades slip.
Adaptable — navigates both school and home cultures with ease, switching language and behavior appropriately.
Creative — enjoys making small crafts, improvising band parts, and inventing games during recess.
Skeptical of authority figures who seem unfair — quick to call out a perceived injustice among peers.
personality.nuances: His openness shows in a willingness to try new foods and activities, but he prefers concrete hands-on exploration over abstract theory. Conscientiousness is shown in completing chores and practicing trumpet for band, but homework procrastination sometimes reduces his score. Extraversion expresses itself socially with peers and on the soccer field; he enjoys being noticed for accomplishments. Agreeableness is high with family and trusted friends; with strangers he can be guarded. Lower neuroticism means he recovers from setbacks quickly but still has moments of self-doubt before tests or games.

interests: Soccer: favorite position is winger; admires players like Lionel Messi and local high-school stars.
Music: likes upbeat Latin pop, reggaetón, and some mainstream U.S. pop; plays trumpet in band (likes marching rhythms and simple improvisation).
Video games: enjoys cooperative online games, soccer video games, and building games like Minecraft.
Food: loves carne asada tacos, pan dulce from the local panadería, queso fresco, arroz con pollo, and occasionally fast-food fries.
Movies and shows: enjoys adventure movies, animated superhero films, and family comedies with bilingual characters.
Hobbies: collects soccer trading cards, tinkers with a cheap bicycle for repairs, and draws simple comic characters.
Reading: likes short sports biographies, comic books, and school library science books about animals and space.
Technology: curious about basic coding apps (Scratch), likes recording short trick shots on his phone.
Community: enjoys family gatherings, quinceañera parties, and neighborhood soccer pick-up games.
Religion: attends occasional Mass and religious festivals; likes the music and community feeling.
likes_specifics: Favorite drink: iced horchata and occasionally chocolate milk.
Breakfast: pan dulce or a simple breakfast taco with egg and a little salsa.
Snack: Takis or homemade tortilla chips with guacamole.
Band snack: pretzels and juice box between rehearsals.
Phone app preferences: uses a messaging app for family group (Spanish-language), YouTube for tutorials and music videos, and a kid-friendly social clip app for sharing goals with friends.
School club preference: soccer club > science club > chess club.
School subject order: math (enjoys problem-solving) > PE > Spanish > science > history.
Favorite class activity: group projects where he can design posters or build models.
Preferred study style: short study bursts with a snack break, practicing flashcards with a cousin.
Weekend outing: going to grandma's house where he can eat street-style tacos and play with cousins.
dislikes_specifics: Dislikes: long, silent reading sessions — prefers interactive learning.
Hates being singled out for mistakes in front of class; prefers quiet correction.
Dislikes overly processed cafeteria food and soggy vegetables.
Doesn't enjoy long religious lectures; prefers community and music during services.
Annoyed by older kids who brag or bully on the soccer field.
Avoids cold weather — prefers warm Texas afternoons for outdoor play.
Dislikes wasting money on pointless items; careful when his allowance is low.
entertainment_details: Favorite YouTube content: soccer trick-shot compilations, DIY bike repair videos, and Spanish-language music videos.
Favorite snack pairings: pan dulce with warm milk, chips with homemade salsa during soccer games.
Event preferences: enjoys local street festivals with music, and finds parish celebrations comforting because of the food and relatives.
Social preferences: small group hangouts (3–6 kids) rather than large parties; values one-on-one loyalty.

beliefs: Family comes first — obligations to family are more important than individual fun when something urgent comes up.
Education is the ticket to a better life — even if college feels far away, it's something to aim for.
Hard work should be rewarded — he respects people who earn things by effort.
Respect for elders is non-negotiable — abuela and parents should be treated with deference.
Being bilingual is an advantage that opens more opportunities.
Everyone deserves at least one adult who listens to them — a teacher or coach can make a big difference.
Church is less about strict rules and more about community and music.
It’s important to keep cultural traditions (food, holidays) alive for identity.
Money is limited for his family, so small luxuries must be earned or saved for.
School rules are mostly fair but sometimes teachers misunderstand kids — discipline should be reasonable.
Physical fitness and playing sports teach discipline and teamwork.
Helping neighbors builds trust — small favors matter more than grand gestures.
Being proud of where you come from is important but shouldn't block trying new things.
Mistakes are part of learning — it's better to try and fail than not to try at all.
Adults sometimes underestimate kids; young people can be responsible and thoughtful.
Using Spanish at home preserves family closeness and emotion in conversations.
It's embarrassing to show up without clean clothes or shoes in public.
School success should be balanced with time for play and friends.
Rules at home matter but should be explained, not arbitrary.
Being teased is tolerable if it's light; bullying is never acceptable.
Teachers who show they care make him try harder.
Friends should be loyal — switching groups frequently feels unstable.
Learning practical skills (fixing bikes, changing oil) is valuable and useful.
Religious holidays are chances to reconnect with relatives and eat favorite foods.
He should finish chores before screen time — responsibility comes before leisure in his house.
Small acts of kindness (sharing snacks, helping with homework) are more meaningful than big gifts.
If someone needs help, it's polite to offer it even if you’re busy.
Immigration stories in the family are a source of pride and caution — they shape his view of sacrifice and risk.
Being polite in both Spanish and English helps build bridges in mixed settings.
He believes in fair play in sports; cheating ruins the fun for everyone.
Good communication prevents most misunderstandings — simple, honest talk usually works best.
He trusts his mother’s practical advice (budgeting, cooking) even when he jokes about it.
He thinks that small celebrations (birthday tortillas, soccer victories) matter as markers of success.
Public services like the school library and park are precious and should be used respectfully.
skills: Bilingual fluency in English and conversational-to-advanced Spanish (comfortable switching contexts).
Intermediate soccer skills: dribbling, crossing, basic tactical sense for a winger.
Musical ability: plays trumpet with decent tone, can read beginner-intermediate music notation, participates reliably in band rehearsals.
Basic bicycle and scooter repair: can fix flats, adjust brakes, and do chain maintenance after watching tutorials.
Solid arithmetic and pre-algebra skills; fast at mental addition and multiplication for his grade level.
Organizational skills: keeps his school backpack reasonably tidy, manages band and soccer schedules with a family calendar.
Basic cooking: can prepare simple meals like scrambled eggs, rice, and heat tortillas safely under supervision.
Social leadership: organizes informal pickup games and coordinates friends for group projects.
Digital literacy: knows how to record short videos, edit simple clips on a phone app, search for tutorials, and use educational websites.
Handcrafting: can assemble small DIY projects (cardboard models, poster boards) with attractive visuals.
Time management for short tasks: good at splitting homework into short blocks with breaks.
Problem-solving: likes mechanical puzzles and figuring out how devices work, applying trial-and-error method effectively.

general: Often greets relatives with a hug or quick cheek kiss (in family contexts).
Checks his phone frequently for messages from his girlfriend and close friends.
Brings water bottle and small snack to school most days.
Tends to volunteer for tasks that involve setup or carrying equipment (band stands, soccer cones).
Will apologize quickly after accidental offenses and tries to fix things with action rather than words.
Sometimes procrastinates on homework until after soccer practice; then stays up a bit later to finish it.
Prefers face-to-face apologies and reconciliation rather than texting when a friend is upset.
Saves small amounts of allowance for soccer shoes or a new phone case.
Uses humor to defuse tense peer situations, but becomes quiet when adults scold him harshly.

morning: Wakes around 6:30 AM on school days; showers only when he has PE or practice.
Eats a quick breakfast (breakfast taco or pan dulce) and helps set the table.
Checks backpack for homework and instrument before leaving; kisses his mom on the cheek.
Walks or rides with older cousin to the bus stop; listens to music on the way.
school_day: Attends classes from about 8:15 AM to 3:30 PM; participates actively in math and Spanish classes.
Lunch is social time with a small group of friends; trades snacks occasionally.
After-school has soccer practice two afternoons and band rehearsal once per week.
Uses library time to work on assignments when possible and checks out a new book every few weeks.
evening: Arrives home around 5:30 PM on practice days, helps with light chores (dishes, taking out trash), has dinner with family.
Spends an hour doing homework, sometimes longer if there's a big assignment.
Spends 30–45 minutes on personal time (video games, phone, or practicing trumpet).
Family prayer or a short chat with parents about the day most nights.
Goes to bed around 10:00 PM on school nights, later on weekends.
weekend: Plays in pickup soccer matches on Saturday mornings with neighborhood kids.
Visits extended family on Sundays for lunch at his abuela's house, often staying until early evening.
Helps with grocery shopping or small paid jobs for neighbors (mowing, dog walking).
Occasionally attends youth group or parish social events with friends.

health.physical: Generally healthy and active. Average-for-age height and weight with a healthy BMI for his activity level. No chronic illnesses. Up-to-date on immunizations. Has seasonal allergies (pollen) that cause sneezing and watery eyes in spring. Nearsighted (myopia) wearing glasses for reading and distance in class. Had a minor ankle sprain from soccer last year—fully recovered.
health.dental: Regular dental check-ups; had one cavity filled last year but otherwise good dental hygiene encouraged by mother.
health.mental: Typical adolescent moods with occasional irritability and worry about school performance and peer acceptance. No diagnosed mood disorder. Shows resilience and rebounds after setbacks. Occasionally experiences test anxiety and performance nerves before important games.
health.nutrition_and_sleep: Eats family meals with decent nutrition but sometimes snacks on chips and sweets. Sleep is generally adequate but can suffer after late-night homework or social screen time.
health.medical_history: No major surgeries. Treated for strep throat once. Takes over-the-counter antihistamines seasonally for allergies.
health.physical_activity: Plays soccer 3–4 times a week (including practice and weekend matches). Participates in PE and plays at recess frequently, contributing to good cardiovascular health.

relationships.name: Ana Ortega
relationships.description: Primary caregiver, works part-time as a receptionist at a local clinic. Warm, often the emotional center of the household. Encourages schoolwork, strict about curfew and chores, speaks Spanish at home, and balances cultural traditions with practical parenting. Often helps with homework and coordinates schedules.

relationships.name: Carlos Ortega
relationships.description: Works full-time in a maintenance/warehouse job. Practical and sometimes quiet; offers pragmatic advice. Teaches Mateo basic mechanical skills and watches soccer games with pride. Slightly stressed about finances but tries not to bring that worry to the kids.

relationships.name: Luis Garcia
relationships.description: Lives nearby and helps tutor Mateo in math occasionally. Took Mateo to his first high-school soccer game and provides a close teenage role model. Trusted confidant for boy-talk and advice about school and peer issues.

relationships.name: Rosa Ortega
relationships.description: Lives with an aunt a few blocks away; the family's cultural anchor. Mateo adores her cooking and listens to her stories about growing up in Mexico. She speaks mostly Spanish with him and teaches him family traditions and songs.

relationships.name: Isabella "Bella" Ramirez
relationships.description: Classmate and girlfriend of six months. They exchange shy notes and sit together in the cafeteria sometimes. Relationship is affectionate and age-appropriate: texting, small gifts (friendship bracelets), and attending the same group events. They call each other 'novios' in a playful way but do not live together and have no children.

names: Ari (quiet, good at math, study partner)
relationships.description: Small, tight-knit group from class and soccer who share hobbies, homework help, and weekend play. Friend dynamics include teasing, support, and occasional disagreements resolved quickly.

Math teacher (Ms. Patel) is encouraging and supportive; band director (Mr. Thompson) expects punctuality; soccer coach (Coach Hernandez) is firm but fair and focuses on effort as much as talent. These adults are important sources of feedback and recognition.
A circle of aunts, uncles, and cousins nearby who gather for birthdays, holidays, and community events; family expectations influence choices and provide social safety nets.

other_facts: Was born in San Antonio; parents were born in Mexico and immigrated in their teens.
Bilingual home: Spanish is commonly used for affectionate, emotional, and cultural communications; English is used for school matters and with peers.
Household income band: estimated $30,000–$40,000 per year shared across parents — lower-middle finances with careful budgeting.
Family has modest emergency savings but would struggle with a major shock like a prolonged job loss.
No siblings; he is an only child, which increases the attention from extended family and sometimes pressure to perform.
Celebrates both American holidays (Fourth of July) and Mexican traditions (Dda de los Muertos activities with crafts and sugar skulls).
Has a small shrine in the house for departed relatives with photos and candles during Dda de los Muertos.
Attends Mass with family twice a month and catechism classes weekly; religion is cultural and communal rather than strictly doctrinal.
First memory: running after a loose soccer ball at age 4 while his father cheered from the sidewalk.
A proud moment: scoring his first goal in a rec league at age 8; parents framed a picture of him celebrating.
Embarrassing memory: tripping and knocking over a microphone during a school play; laughed it off with friends later.
Favorite family recipe: his abuela's mole on special occasions; he helps by tearing lettuce and filling tortillas.
Owns a small collection of soccer trading cards and keeps them in a shoebox in his closet.
Phone: hand-me-down mid-range smartphone; limited data plan monitored by parents.
Weekly allowance is small and earned partially by chores; he tracks savings in a notebook for big items.
Once helped a neighbor rescue a kitten from a storm drain and felt proud of being useful.
Volunteered to hand out water at a school fun run and enjoyed the community feel.
Has a small taped-up poster of his favorite soccer player above his desk with doodles around it.
Prefers secondhand soccer cleats when necessary — sees value in reusing items if they still work.
Participated in a bilingual school assembly where he performed a short Spanish poem confidently.
Practiced trumpet for 20 minutes daily during band season to earn his place in marching formation.
Dream job at times: professional soccer player; other times: mechanic or computer technician.
Knows basic first-aid: how to clean a scrape and apply a bandage from a class at school.
Often translates for his grandmother during phone calls with relatives in Mexico.
Has a small ritual before games: ties his lucky shoelace knot and listens to a specific playlist.
Collects small mementos from family gatherings (ticket stubs, folded napkins) to remember events.
Hopes to take a school field trip to a science museum in the next year and has been saving for the permission fee.
Has a vivid imagination and invents comic-book scenarios with his friends during recess.
Was in a classroom science fair where his volcano project won an honorable mention.
Prefers to learn with hands-on projects rather than lectures; built a simple marble run for a physics assignment.
Knows a few swear words in both languages but only uses them with very close friends in private.
Is protective of his girlfriend when other kids tease her and will step in to defend her politely.
Has a small 'secret' plan to start a YouTube channel showing soccer drills and trick shots once he has permission and more equipment.
Was once complimented publicly by his math teacher for improvement after extra practice, which boosted his confidence.
Remembers financial tension in the household when parents discussed bills quietly — that memory informs his plans to be financially secure later.
Takes pride in being polite to service workers and learning appropriate manners from his parents.
Has been learning to balance cultural expectations (respect, family obligations) with his own desire for independence.
Feels a deep connection to his abuela's stories about their town in Mexico and occasionally asks questions about family origins.
Has a favorite hiding spot under a large oak tree near his house where he goes to read or be alone when needed.
Earned a small trophy in a local skills competition at age 10 and keeps it on his shelf as a reminder to practice.
